article.title: Restoring a 1984 IBM PC
article.author: Bongo404
article.excerpt: Journey through the restoration of a classic IBM PC, from cleaning to getting it boot-ready. Discover the challenges and triumphs of bringing vintage tech back to life.

content.text: When I first laid eyes on the dusty IBM PC 5150 at a local estate sale, I knew I had found something special. This iconic machine, released in 1981, represented the beginning of the PC revolution. But it was in rough shape—covered in decades of dust, with yellowed plastic and mysterious stains on the keyboard.
Before diving into any restoration project, it's crucial to assess what you're working with. I carefully inspected the machine, noting several issues that needed attention:

items: Heavy dust accumulation inside and out
Yellowed plastic case from UV exposure

content.text: I started with a complete disassembly. Every screw was carefully removed and organized. The keyboard received special attention—each keycap was removed and soaked in warm, soapy water. The PCB was gently cleaned with isopropyl alcohol and a soft brush.

content.alt: Disassembled IBM PC showing internal components
content.caption: The IBM PC completely disassembled for cleaning

content.text: The yellowed plastic was the biggest cosmetic issue. I used the 'retr0bright' method—a hydrogen peroxide solution activated by UV light. After 8 hours in the sun, the transformation was remarkable. The beige plastic had returned to its original color.

content.code:
Retr0bright Recipe:
- 12% Hydrogen Peroxide
- 1 tsp Oxy powder per liter
- Apply gel to plastic
- Expose to UV light for 6-8 hours
- Rinse and dry thoroughly

content.text: This is always the moment of truth. I carefully inspected the power supply, looking for bulging capacitors or signs of damage. Everything looked good, so I performed a slow power-up test using a variac to gradually increase voltage.
Success! The machine powered on, and after connecting a monitor, I was greeted with the beautiful sight of the ROM BASIC prompt. The system was alive!

With the machine working, I focused on the finishing details. I sourced period-correct expansion cards from online auctions, installed a CGA graphics card, and added a 5.25-inch floppy drive. After loading PC DOS 3.3, the restoration was complete.

This restoration taught me patience and respect for vintage technology. These machines were built to last, and with proper care, they can continue functioning decades later. The most important lessons were:

items: Never force components—if it doesn't fit, you're doing it wrong
Test incrementally—don't reassemble everything before testing
Join vintage computing communities for advice and support

content.text: Now this 1984 IBM PC sits proudly on my desk, a working piece of computing history. Every time I boot it up and hear that satisfying beep, I'm reminded of the ingenuity and craftsmanship that went into these early personal computers.
